description.narrative: The Fair, Green and Global Alliance (FGG) aims to increase the power and decision-making influence of organised, mobilised and informed civil society, especially women, to advance fair and green trade and value chains. FGG believes that poverty, inequality and exclusion are caused by power asymmetries. We see the unprecedented power of capital over people and planet as the primary obstacle impeding realisation of fair and green trade and value chains. The FGG programme focuses on recalibrating power within the global architecture of trade and value chains by amplifying the voices of targeted rights-holders – small producers and traders, workers, fishers, rural and Indigenous peoples, religious and ethnic minorities, and migrants, especially the women and youth among them – who are practising, claiming or defending human rights and fair and green economic practices, and/or whose rights are being ignored, threatened or violated by corporations and/or governments. We aim to transform social relations so that these rights-holders’ voices are heard and heeded. FGG’s eight members (ActionAid, Both ENDS, Clean Clothes Campaign, IT for Change, Milieudefensie/Friends of the Earth International/Friends of the Earth Europe, Samdhana Institute, SOMO and the Transnational Institute) cooperate with some 1000+ partners and allies in our many worldwide networks to strengthen collective capacities to advance a common vision of fair and green trade and value chains.
agenda-setting, momentum-building and increased support
# key actors (government, private sector, other) who put FGG policy/practice recommendations on their agendas (e.g. meetings, debates, media coverage)

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for at least 3 actors (central government, ministries and state governments in India but also important important multilateral bodies such as the UNCTAD and the ILO) to incorporate policy recommendations on inclusive and fair digital economies, data, platform and AI governance, corporate regulation through the UN Binding Treaty and protecting worker rights in digital value chains on their agenda.

description.narrative: agenda-setting, momentum-building and increased support
# of instances in which the recommendation a key actor puts on its agenda aims to contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: Of these 3 actors, we aim for at least 1 actor (multilateral/other actor/key decision makers in governments) to put our recommendations on defending/expanding civic space on their agenda. We expect this will concern, among others, the engagement of civil society in digital trade policy implicating worker rights and public services.

description.narrative: agenda-setting, momentum-building and increased support
# of instances in which the recommendation a key actor puts on its agenda aims to contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: Of these 3 actors, we aim for 1 actor to put our recommendation on gender equality on their agenda, mainly concerning the inclusion of women in the digital economy, the gendered modus operadi of platform capitalism, and integrating a gender-perspective in policies governing the digital economy, including data and AI governance.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for at least 1 instance, where a government institution from India or similar decision maker from Asia/Africa will adopt our recommendations on inclusive and fair trade and investment agreements for the governance of digital trade, that protects workers rights and preserves the regulatory capacities of developing countries.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (likely policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on trade agreements, with specific reference to the place of worker rights and the regulatory capacities of developing countries.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for a government institution from India or similar decision maker from Asia/Africa to adopt our policy recommendation for the expansion of input spaces and mechanisms for civil society actors into the digital trade space

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for one instance in which a government institution from India adopts our recommendations on on gender-responsive digital trade rules and policies that expand the scope of women’s participation in global digital value chains.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# of instances in which the supported and/or promoted recommendation by a key actor aims to contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (likely policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendation for the expansion of input spaces and mechanisms for civil society actors into the digital trade space.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# of instances in which the supported and/or promoted recommendation by a partner aims to contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on gender-responsive digital trade rules and policies that expand the scope of women’s participation in global digital value chains.

description.narrative: governments regulating the private sector
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for at least 2 instances, where a government institution from India will adopt our recommendations for governance of the digital economy and regulation of Big Tech corporations.

description.narrative: governments regulating the private sector
# key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 2 actors (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on governing corporate conduct and businesses in the digital economy, with specific reference to the UN Binding Treaty, and the governance of Big Tech companies and platforms operating in the Global South.

description.narrative: governments regulating the private sector
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for a government institution from India to adopt our recommendations for the expansion of input spaces and mechanisms for civil society actors into governance spaces for the digital economy.

description.narrative: governments regulating the private sector
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for one instance in which a government institution from India adopts our recommendations, which will include gender justice components, such as for instance important social care policies that can work to alleviate womens’ care burdens, expand social protection for platform workers,, on governance of the digital economy and Big Tech.

# of instances in which the supported and/or promoted recommendation by a key actor aims to contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendation for the expansion of input spaces and mechanisms for civil society actors into governance spaces for the digital economy.

# of instances in which the supported and/or promoted recommendation by a partner aims to contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations, which will include gender justice components, on governance of the digital economy and Big Tech.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: In 2022, we hope that in at least 1 instance, a government institution from India will adopt our recommendations on creating enabling national digital infrastructure policies for fair value chains.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 3 actors (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on enabling national infrastructure policies on the digital economy in India.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for one actor to adopt our recommendations for the expansion of consultative processes within national digital infrastructure policy processes

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for one instance in which a government institution from India adopts our recommendations, which will include gender justice components towards expanding equitable participation for women in digital value chains, through enabling national digital infrastructure policies.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# of instances in which the supported and/or promoted recommendation by a key actor aims to contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (likely policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendation for the expansion of consultative processes within national digital infrastructure policy processes.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# of instances in which the supported and/or promoted recommendation by a partner aims to contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations, which will include gender justice components, on national digital infrastructure policies.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development
governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# of laws, policies and norms/attitudes, blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development
process
learning sessions organised by FGG members and partner organisations

comment.narrative: We will organize learning sessions on digital economy issues and their intersections with value chains for FGG consortium members as well as partner organizations.. We also view the opportunity to engage with long term partners as well as new members to our networks in the FGG program as a way to expand our learning with respect to issues, strategies and responses. Our work will be informed and modified by these collaborative processes.

description.narrative: process
lines of work in which FGG members and partners build upon gender analysis and incorporate gender justice in their strategy

comment.narrative: Gender justice is a critical component of all the work that we will be doing under the FGG program. Specifically, we will be focussing on research on women in digital value chains, gender and e-commerce, gender issues wrt women workers in the digital economy.

description.narrative: process
the extent to and ways in which FGG involves local groups in the design and implementation of the FGG programme

comment.narrative: We will work with local partners closely to seek inputs and contextualize various collaborative iniatitives planned under FGG. Both at the design and implementation stage of projects and iniaiatives planned under FGG, we will reach out to local partners for consultations and discussions . We will work with partners in India, Indonesia, Philippines and broadly in Asia-Pacific and Latin America

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# of CSOs included in the FGG programme
strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors that lobby and advocate for improved policies and practices in trade and value chains and advance fair and green practices based on capacities mutually developed

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for 5 CSOs, located mainly in Asia-Pacific (India), Latin America and Africa to lobby and advocate for improving trade and investment agreements, with a focus on digital trade rules and chapters. Our focus will be on 1. ensuring treaties do not undermine workers rights nor the regulatory spaces of developing countries to pursue their own digital development agendas, 2. appropriate corporate regulation and data governance regimes 3. infrastructural policy initiatives and alternative models . This will be done through knowledge building in the domain, joint strategizing and coordination.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities contributing to and/or relevant for lobby and advocacy aiming at expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: We will strengthen capacities of all 10 CSOs towards expanding/defending civic space. We envision this goal to be an outcome of work done through our capacity development initiatives, our knowledge partnerships as well as joint strategizing activities on digital justice issues. Through this work, we will enable CSOs to assert/amplify their voices in fora where policies on the digital economy are being debated – both at the national and international levels. An important focus of our work will be to reclaim global governance spaces around the digital for civil society voice and deliberative democartic processes that have increasingly fallen prey to corporature capture.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities for lobbying and advocacy

comment.narrative:
We aim for 10 civil society actors, located in India, Asia-Pacific, Latin America and Africa to have strengthened their capacities to recognize and grasp digital intersections within global value chains and advocate for fairer outcomes. This includes for instance worker rights for emerging digital economy contexts, appropriate data policies, regulation of corporate conduct of tech companies, better digital taxation and competition policies.
Towards this aim, we will engage in mutual capacity development activities such as knowledge exchange through meetings and round tables, networking and trainings, joint strategizing and campaigning.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities relevant to advance gender justice

comment.narrative: Of these 10 CSOs, we will strengthen the capacities of 3 CSOs (In India and globally) to better lobby and advocacy for gender justice in the digital economy, through weaving in gender justice components such as women’s economic rights and equal participation in digital value chains, into our capacity building initiatives and knowledge exercises.
